sentence: Every week, Marc Chaikin applies his groundbreaking analysis to an ETF or a sector.
Today, he looks at the SPDR Consumer Discretionary Select Sector ETF (XLY).
The SPDR Consumer Discretionary Select Sector ETF (XLY) reflects the large cap consumer discretionary stocks in the S&P 500 Index.
The XLY has been trading well, in part due to the sharp drop in the price of crude oil.
The Chaikin Power Bar differentials are now neutral, having improved with the better price performance of the XLY.
The Power Bar rankings of the XLY show an improving differential between bullish and bearish Chaikin Power Gauge stock ratings.
The XLY has 15 stocks with bullish a Chaikin Power Gauge rating vs. 15 with bearish ratings.
When we look at all 9 SPDR Select Sector ETFs, we see the XLY as having mid-range potential based on the difference between bullish and bearish Chaikin Power Gauge ratings.
The way to benefit from increased demand for Consumer Discretionary stocks and the XLY is to divide your sector allocation between the XLY and the strongest stocks in the XLY as indicated below.
Use short-term dips to buy the XLY as the persistent Relative Strength vs. the S&P 500 Index suggests that the Consumer Discretionary sector will outperform the market over the next three months.
As noted above, the SPDR Consumer Discretionary Select Sector ETF (XLY) has 15 bullish rated Power Gauge stocks vs. 15 with bearish ratings as indicated by the Chaikin Power Bar for the XLY.
The stocks with bullish Power Gauge potential in the XLY over the next 3 â€“ 6 months have a common theme.
They are stocks with primarily U.S. revenue and are not negatively impacted by the strength of the U.S. dollar.
In addition, they will benefit from consumer spending patterns, as positive consumer confidence results in more spending on discretionary items.
The obvious trigger is the lower price of gasoline at the pump which is putting over $150 billion dollars in the pockets of the American consumer.
The Chaikin Portfolio Health Check is an excellent tool to help zero in on the strongest stocks in any ETF; in the XLY there are 15 bullish-rated stocks.

By looking at the individual component stocks through the lens of the 20 factor, Chaikin Power Gauge stock rating model, you can easily find the stocks in the XLY ETF with the strongest price potential over the next 3-6 months.
When these individual bullish rated stocks also outperform the broad market, they can be bought in addition to the XLY, which is trading well.
The Chaikin Power Grid in Portfolio Health Check (see below) maps stocks and industry groups from strong to weak so you can easily determine the best and worst stocks in any ETF.

To find the strongest stocks in the XLY, we look to the upper right quadrant of the Power Grid (strong Power Gauge stocks in strong industry groups) where we find stocks with the best potential for price gains over the next 3-6 months.

Here we see stocks like Whirlpool (WHR), which reported better than expected earnings this morning, Staples (SPLS), which announced the acquisition of Office Depot today, Lowes (LOW), which is benefiting from home improvement trends along with Home Depot (HD), Petsmart (PETM) and Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY).
The common theme amongst all these stocks is that they derive almost all of their revenue from domestic sources, making them immune from the negative effects of a strong U.S. dollar.

Stocks in the upper left quadrant, (weak Power Gauge stocks in strong Industry Groups), like Tiffany (TIF), Mattel (MAT), Nike (NKE), Garmin (GRMN) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), which reported disappointing earnings this morning, should be swapped for stronger stocks in those industry groups like Bed Bath & Beyond, Electronic Arts (EA), and Auto Zone (AZO).

The weakest stocks in the XLY, in weak Media group, like Scripps Network (SNI), Discovery Communications (DISCA) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) should be sold because the bearish Power Gauge rating indicates negative potential over the next 3-6 months.
Over time, strong stocks in strong industry groups will outperform the market.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
